description: Hugh's Room is a concert hall recently relocated to 296 Broadview Avenue in the Riverdale / East Chinatown neighbourhood of Toronto. Our original home operated on Dundas Street West from 2001 until 2020. This new location opened in Sept of 2023 featuring live music from a variety of genres - primarily folk, jazz, global and other independent legacy and emerging artists in an intimate 200 seat concert setting. There is no longer a restaurant component to the venue. Live music is presented most nights Wednesday to Saturday with occasional Tuesday and Sunday (aft and evening) shows. Hugh's Room is a registered charitable cultural instituion.

reviews.title: Great Live Music in Toronto
text: So happy to have found this great spot for live music in Toronto!  I used to go to the "old" Hughes Room but I like this new location much more.  The building was originally a church which means that the space is wide open and comfortable and the accoustics are excellent.  I prefer a smaller, more intimate venue and really enjoy catching live performances - something that has become harder to find in recent years - so this spot is a goldmine.  Lots of variety to the shows - different styles of music and different artists - which I really appreciate.  I also love that they provide a stage to local and well as international talent.

reviews.title: Support live music!
text: Yes the food isn’t the draw here, though I did have an enjoyable burger there last week. I got some tickets to see JV’s Boogaloo Squad and decided to treat some like minded friends. The band was great, the service good, the beer and burger satisfying and my wife and friends had a great time. It’s a great music venue, a registered charity and a mediocre restaurant. The tickets were cheap by most standards and very cheap considering we were 20 feet from the stage with an unobstructed view! I did make a donation as music venues are closing because they can’t turn a profit due to skyrocketing rents. Thanks dirty money. This is why they decided to become a non profit. This room has some amazing acts passing through, its intimate, the sound is great and they do it day after day. If you don’t like the food, eat before the show but get out and support live music, you won’t regret it. Love to Hugh’s Room Live!

reviews.title: Hugh's Room. Good food and excellent music!
text: We visited Hugh's Room to see the  Albert Lee band perform.  They were amazing.
Also had a tasty and enjoyable dinner.

reviews.title: Incredible potential if they fix the menu!
text: Last night we went with friends to listen to music ! It was tribute night for James Taylor! My favourite type of evening. The show started at 8:30 and they stagger the dinner so that they can feed everyone. We were there at 6 pm. We ordered and most of the food was good but the Cobb salad my friend and I ordered was disgusting! Mostly lettuce with a garlic aioli dressing that did not even go , a tiny piece of bacon a tsp of soggy crab meat from a frozen package and that was about it! I was offered something else but unfortunately due to my new lifestyle of eating Keto there was not much else I could get! I want them to fix this! There is no excuse for terrible food! Check online and see what is in a Cobb salad please! Don’t charge $17 for lettuce if you are not going to deliver please! Your venue delivers amazing music and I would love to return for many evenings! Please learn to make good food!

reviews.title: Enjoyable live music Venue
text: Hugh's Room has a long history and we were glad to see it re-opened after it closed for a period of time.  If you enjoy live music, this is a superb venue that does it well. The atmosphere is intimate, the chocolate cake we had was delicious.  The people who work here are very passionate about the music industry they support.

reviews.title: Great venue, too bad about the food
text: First time at Hugh's room to see Jack Dekeyser. Awesome sightlines and sound. We all ordered dinner. The Cobb Salad was nothing but a plate of mixed greens with a mashed up pile of fake crab hiding underneath! No cheese. Half an egg. Sent both back and went for the only dessert available and highly recommended by the server; chocolate coconut cake. When it arrived 30 minutes later it was so hard I had to use a knife to cut it. Extremely mediocre burger for $23.
Go to Hugh's for the music BUT eat before you go.

reviews.title: Awesome Live Music, Slow Service and Mediocre Food
text: I have been to Hugh's Room many times and always enjoyed the experience. It's a great music listening/watching venue and the food has always been good. Nothing too creative but good. Not any more. The only thing at our table of five that was yummy was the french fries. The "picnic" was a joke (tiny Charcuterie board with a few dry biscuits, slim amount of cheese and some meat). They ran out of both green salads (and we were there early) so served us some wilted kale. The wine is horribly overpriced and the service was so slow we gave up waiting after 15 minutes and ordered a bottle of wine directly at the bar. Our waiter was funny and nice but they truly does not make up for bad service. I love this place and would love to see it thrive. This will not happen with bad food, bad service and then the begging for money (it is now a non-profit) - not so cool. I might suggest a new menu, more servers and wine that is worth the inflated price. Keep up the awesome music!

reviews.title: First evening at Hugh's Room
text: Staff were very pleasant, service was good, beer was good, food was good, and the prices were good.
We ended up seated right by the stage for Mary Fahl, and it wasn't at all too loud.
Altogether a friendly, comfortable night out.

reviews.title: Wonderful venue for music - the size and layout of the room are perfect
text: I went to see Alfie Zappacosta perform in September 2019. I had never seen him perform before, and I had no idea that he was SO funny. The music was fantastic - that voice, oh that voice! - but his comments during the show made a wonderful evening even better.  The size of the room makes the musical experience very intimate, which is normally a good thing. However, this evening, there was one woman in the audience who did her best to spoil the show for everyone with her antics: standing up (and being told more than once to sit down), waving her arms around, shouting at the stage. In fact, even Alfie looked at her, frowned and shook his head. But where was the management? I saw a staff member speak to her during the intermission, in the typical apologetic Canadian fashion. She should have been given a couple of warnings and then ejected. And the food. Hmmm. The burger was delicious, and for $21.00 it should be. Dessert - ONE choice. Passion fruit cheesecake. I saw one person order it - one person, in a room of 200. All the other reviews are correct. It's a wonderful venue for music lovers, but management needs to do a lot of work in the food service department. The prices are not cheap, but the quality of the food certainly is.
And please, do not let one person hijack everyone's evening just because she doesn't know how to behave.

reviews.title: Great music - so why isn't Hughs listening to us - the food so limited, boring and has just plain weird selections
text: I have been a regular at Hugh's Room for many years and have introduced many folks to the venue. I even donate to the place. It's a cool place to hang out and the servers are usually very personable and hospitable. But why the menu continues to be so seriously out of step and "uncool" for the venue, I can't say. I am going there tonight and I took a peek at the menu to see if it had changed - don't know why I bother to look and hope.  It seems to have gotten worse not better - at least under the other chef they had a few more selections. They continue to miss the opportunity to improve it. I see a lot of people book a table and just not eat. Tonight is Alfie Zappacosta - wouldn't even a few thematic additions to the menu make sense - match them to the type of music? Judging from the other reviews it seems that no one is listening. Anyone in there Hughs? Hellooooooooo.... All I can recommend to you is go for the music folks, and eat before you go.

reviews.title: Music is the show, food a poorly delivered afterthought
text: Interesting spot, now run by an NFP committed to good live music. And they do that part well.

It's also a restaurant. The staff, while generally quite friendly, seem amateurish. We had strange, or poor, or no service from a few different people. Errors were made with our order, things forgotten, allergies ignored or misunderstood.
The menu is a little odd. It's a la carte and sharing is suggested. But the plates are brought out separately, so veg preceded meat by 20 minutes or more. Good enough flavour.
I guess I'd go again, if the entertainment was good enough.

reviews.title: Review is for food, not music. Music was awesome.
text: The night started a little rough when we went to see our old school classmate Jory Nash perform because there was a wall between us and our friends. We knew the wall would be there but did not expect that it would obstruct our own view of the stage for half the people at our stable.

It is a very atmospheric and pretty large space. There is zero natural light so if you are going to take photos of anything that is not on stage I recommend using a flash, something I never do (including the photos I have added to this post that have been heavily edited). For those with disabilities, there are some steps at the front of the space and down to the seating area. The hardest is the bathroom. Lots and lots of stairs.

My cosmo was excellent. Overall I think everyone was happy about their drinks. It was the food that was the issue. Sadly, Hugh's Room lived up to its bad reputation for not very good food. Small portions, full prices so it it supposed to be tapas style but only one thing impressed us. The sirloin which was very rare and not medium the way the menu described. Still, tender and very flavourful.

That said, the night began with over-priced fries that were not particularly good, over-salted croquettes (we all agreed on that one) and a plain but not thrilling Burrata Caprese Salad. The underwhelming salad and small portion of fries did not surprise me but the croquettes being so salty worried me.
The fried Quebec cheese curds was absolutely flavourless and the pieces were so small that all you could really taste was the breading. That plain tomato sauce sure did not help.

The Prosciutto Ravioli with sundried tomatoes came in a rustic red sauce. You know I love pasta but this was too thick and tough. Unforgivable. There were quite a few sundried tomatoes but where the hell was the prosciutto? I think I had one small bite. #whereisthemeat?

This is the place to drink and listen to music. Come on a full stomach. The worst thing you can do to me as a food writer is bore me. The second thing is not know how to make pasta. The third thing is over-seasoning the food. A good sirloin is not going to save you but you can make one hell of a drink. ~ Suzie the Foodie

reviews.title: Good music, not so good food.
text: The Wintergarden Orchestra was our chosen music for the night - always great and entertaining. Full marks.
The MC for the evening lacked stage presence - could have been more enthusiastic and charismatic.

The food and food service however, needs copious improvement. The menu has been changed to a new 'tapas' style which in itself is not bad. The order is taken by the waiter and sent to the kitchen via computer tablet and that's where the continuity ends. The food arrives by separate bus staff not as a complete order but rather in a random order. It's not very savoury and some of the dishes were only warm. Cutlery was taken away before the next dish arrived and it took 2 - 3 efforts to get what we needed (we asked for the waiter and bus staff kept arriving with something else in hand). As a restaurant, there needs to be considerable improvement (are you listening Chef?)
Value for food - not good.

reviews.title: Food
text: Have been coming here for years....but never for the food.
Before the closure/restructuring we knew the menu by heart;  knew what we were getting into.
Last visit in Dec, after the re opening, there was a new menu which was ‘OK’. Not a major improvement.
Tonight still waiting for the show (which I’m sure will be terrific)- that is their claim to fame and why we always will come back, the new tapas -sharing menu is another fail.

Food comes at various times. We shared the Tomato-Burrato caprese salad. And that’s what it was; sliced tomatoes and 2 chunks of soft cheese. No olive oil or seasoning which we requested and made a difference. Then came the casserole of zucchini-tomatoes- Parmesan; again absolutely no seasoning whatever. Next was the tasteless and hard prosciutto (really? Could have fooled me ) ravioli which was totally uncooked and beyond ‘al dente. Then the sirloin and that made me realize we had not been asked how we wanted it cooked. This was over cooked and tough, but tasty nonetheless. Best shared dish was the ‘from the sea’ which was a mixed grill of calamari, shrimp and octopus with some sort of garlic, parsley marinade. Every dish was totally unadorned. Not sure what the permanent food challenges here are....small kitchen?...... inexperienced chefs?  Inability to really offer dinner to a large crowd in a  short Pre show period of time.
They would do well to rethink the food and perhaps keep it simple (burgers, ribs, pasta and salads) given the lack of culinary savvy.
On with the show:  the Barra MacNeils!

reviews.title: Fantastic music venue!
text: Hugh's Room is a fantastic place to hear good music and enjoy good food.  They have a new 'tapas' style menu with lots of interesting choices.  We were there Friday, May 25 for the fabulous blues music of David Rotundo & Band and to have dinner.  We arrived at 6:00 pm and taken to our reserved table in the upper level right behind the music control console giving us a clear view of the stage.  Our waiter was great and we all enjoyed our food choices.  The music performance started at 8:30 pm with David's band doing a couple of numbers first and then we started to hear this fantastic 'harp' (harmonica) music coming from the back and there was David working his way through the enthusiastic audience.

Wow .... what an incredible night of music and fun!  A surprise visit from another blues harp performer, Jerome Godboo joining in for a couple of numbers really made the evening so special!  Hugh's Room Live is probably one of the best venues in Toronto to enjoy fabulous music in a more intimate setting and enjoy good food & drinks too!

reviews.title: 5 stars for the music, 3 for the food
text: We went with friends to see Harry Manx and Deevah on Friday, May 11th. The music was excellent and lived up to our expectations. Good sound, entertaining performances.

This was our first visit since the restructuring a year ago so we were curious about the food. You'll see in other reviews that "you go for the music, not the food" and the four of us would repeat that caution. The food was better than in the past, the service was better too, but frankly that's not saying much since it was pretty terrible in the past.

The tapas-style approach to the menu did not work well. Three of us had finished our dinner before the fourth dinner arrived. (The recipient is a good-natured fellow so the tardy service did not spoil the evening.) The food itself was ok, but not memorable.The server was friendly but a bit scattered. He needed periodic reminders about our requests.Check out after the concert was delayed because the credit card readers couldn't connect to wifi. The kitchen and servers have more work to do to make this an attractive place to eat.

reviews.title: A Great Venue for Music
text: this is an excellent local for hearing music and  dinner or a drink. The food was served in a small dish Tapas type of format and came out as it was prepared. some dishes were excellent and some so so. With a great local music artist it is a great spot for an evening out.

reviews.title: Saw June Garber on May 2nd
text: The show was great. The venue was perfect for Live Music and we need more of these places in Toronto.

We had dinner and the show...the dinner was funny to say the least. Our waitress was great but the kitchen lacked coordination. Food was coming out whenever and without any form of expediter in the back it was a comedy. The quality of the food was OK not amazing as some of the menu items were unorthodox to say the least.
Because we were there for a couple hours the hiccups from the back didn't bother me, however if you were in there to eat and get out in a hurry, that could be tricky.
They had just re-opened and that is an interesting story, they could really use some experience as it is now a non profit but it shouldn't be run so poorly from an operational perspective.
I will go back for the music probably not the food.

reviews.title: Amazing venue, Great service
text: We went for dinner and show April/18 to see Russell DeCarle.  The venue is really great, you book well in advance for a dinner reservation you can choose a table. Really nice venue for dinner and entertainment.  Show was Great!, Parking across the street in plaza. This night was the first night of a new menu.  Unfortunately dinner was very disappointing,  The waiter explained the menu, best he could. The idea was each dish comes separate, eg. steak, potatoes, vegetables.... the problem was they were having problems getting the food out fast enough. So we received 4 small Potatoes and after more than 20 minutes more potatoes or buns and so on. we never really had all of the parts together. I know it was a first night, but perhaps the type of food is not suitable for this style of serving. Food was not great either. tough steak, char burned asparagus.    I can't say enough about the servers though, they worked very hard and were most pleasant all night. very difficult job for them.
all in all place is great, hope they do something about this menu.

reviews.title: Dinner and  Slambovian Circus of Dreams
text: We (2 couples) were rather concerned going there last evening about the food.. given all the negative reviews, but we were pleasantly surprised!! And our server was fairly attentive, given that the venue was packed - had to be a sold out event.  And the music ... amazing.. we had not heard of the Slambovian Circus of Dreams before (living under a rock..??), and we were just blown away and purchased several CDs!  Keep on keeping on, Hugh's Room!

reviews.title: Good music venue in Toronto
text: A long standing music concert venue and restaurant. Their tiered levels seatings literally makes every table a good spot for their music performance. Service been improved; unfortunately the food quality and quantity dropped after the placed been re-opened after renovation. It is still a great place for music lovers.

reviews.title: Really disappointed as we want to love this place!
text: My husband and I booked dinner and a show with a plan to taste from the new menu. The appetizer servings were on the small side but tasty until my guy found a piece of CIGAR in the salad. Yup an inch long rolled up cigar bit the circumference of a cinnamon stick. Our waitress took it away and then avoided us for about 30 minutes. When she came back we had to ask her about the bit and she said “neither the chef nor the prep team smoke...well one quit a few weeks ago.” Then she asked for our main order. No apology, no nothing. My stomach was a bit turned and so we waited a while. Meanwhile the Opening ACT was the House Manager and she was  not great. In fact she was worse than not great. Eventually the headliner came on and he was super talented and very entertaining. Meanwhile we ordered a “safe” main with a recco from a regular patron. It was fine. Our bill came and there was the salad, including $14 worth of cigar.  My date complained to the bartender and the bill was adjusted. But no apology, nothing. We love Hugh’s Room.~it’s a neighbourhood and city institution. But shoddy service, lame opening acts (in a city brimming with talent) and CIGAR BITS in the food do not bode well for its future. We will go back, not for dinner and only after checking out the talent on SoundCloud or YouTube!

reviews.title: Great Venue
text: First time here. Very relaxed atmosphere, excellent view of the stage and sound for Alfie Zappacosta was super, great show!  The food lived up to other reviews I've read, but to get a table seat, you have to reserve for dinner and arrive 2 hours before the show. The salad was quite plain for the price, and the pork entree was good but quite a small portion. The chocolate mousse made us laugh. It was more the consistency of chocolate frosting which had hardened. The drinks were great as was the service. I would stick with a few items from the sharing menu next time. I do recommend this place and would return, but on a semi full stomach, as we left hungry.

reviews.title: Very Good but Can and Should be Great
text: We were at the first of 2 sold out Shows of Rik Emmett from Triumph.  First of all incredible venue for Live music, really not a bad seat in the entire house.  We were there for dinner and the show.  The hostess was very nice and promptly took us to our table, we were 4 people.  The waiter by the name of "Dave" was sensational, very friendly, professional and enjoys his job, he also made some good food recommendations.

As for the food we good as an Appetizer the "Rations" which was warm fresh bread, Cheese, Pickles and Olives and it was "Outstanding"  I had as the Main a "Cornish Hen", and it was one of the best I ever had.  Another person had the "Beef Tenderloin" and it was very good.

The only major disappointment, was 2 of us had the "Pork Tenderloin" arriving at 2 different times and in both instances, although the quality and presentation of the food was great, the food itself for both people was "Ice Cold" ,  Now the waiter offered to take it back to the Kitchen to "warm it up" but that is never a good thing, cause it can only dry it out.

I mean the place was sold out and it was packed, so they were very busy, but there is no excuse, for 2 plates of food arriving Ice Cold.  We told Management about it and they apologized and were very receptive and said they would look into it.
So on Balance, it would have been a 5 Star Review, if not for the Pork Tenderloin temperature.

Lastly Rik Emmett, 10 Stars **********.  Still one of the most gifted, down to earth, talented Guitarists / Virtuoso Vocalists out there.  He has to be seen and heard Live to be  believed.  So in conclusions we would go back again for sure.

reviews.title: Love the Venue and the Music....(Not the food)
text: I love Hugh’s Rm and have been attending concerts for many years. I have monetarily supported the venue when it closed and reopened thanks to other devotees of this special place. The food before it closed was quite adequate and often delicious and suitably priced. The service has always been good. Since Hugh’s Rm has reopened, the food is a real disappointment. They have tried several approaches, small plates....nope! I was there last Sunday evening for a wonderful jazz night with Barbra Lica. We noted a new menu!  Wow!  I ordered the Cornish Hen and my friend ordered the sirloin. Her meat was siazable but came medium, not medium rare as ordered. The chicken arrived hot, crispy and delicious.....encouraging....BUT....the mashed potatoes were a cold and watery mass underneath the chicken and the Brussels sprouts had been passed over the steamer. Grrr! What is so difficult about providing simple, well prepared food for a reasonable price?  The food quality is beginning to discourage me from entering any further than a stool at the bar.....but hope rules!

reviews.title: My Favourite Listening Room in Toronto
text: For musicians and music lovers alike, Hugh's Room Live is an excellent venue for catching some of the best live music in the city. Since the club reopened, the music programs continues to be excellent and there have been exemplary efforts made in improving the quality of the food program. Along with the beer, I had the burrata, seafood and a dessert. All were excellent. As a west-end native, I'm thrilled to have Hugh's Room open again. It's a gem every Torontonian should have in their pocket.

reviews.title: Excellent for Entertainment but the food leaves a lot to be desired!!!
text: We try to get into Hugh's room several times a year with friends to enjoy an evening together. We were last here in March and loved every minute so we had been really looking forward to last night. The band was fantastic Monkey Junk were worth more than the ticket price, but the food was Absolutely Dreadful! Described to us as 'being like a tapas service' that we could share the food came out of the kitchen at random intervals, cold, uninteresting and tasteless. For heavens sake do not get the ravioli - it was delivered from the kitchen as three dry slabs of pasta with a teaspoon of filling in each. The chicken thighs were crammed into a side dish while the sweet potato fritters were piled on top of one another in the middle of a soup plate. I have no idea how we were meant to share any of it. And after tasting it no one would want to. They need to stop trying to be pretentious with the food and revert to serving simple dishes that are worth eating. Time for a visit from Restaurant makeover!!! And for heavens sake get the ladies toilets fixed!!!!

reviews.title: Excellent small and intimate venue to see a band
text: Lots of bad reviews about the food and the menu. I found both to be just fine. The new menu is made up of small dishes that are meant to be shared around the table. Don't go expecting to have a giant dinner. However after several dishes I had eaten enough. Everything was tasty and served promptly. We drank a nice draft lager too.

Its not super cheap but hey - its downtown Toronto - you want to find cheap see if your favorite band will play in Hamilton. That said it is not expensive either and our band ticket was $20 so it was not an expensive night.
Anyhow you go to Hugh's room for the music and our show was fantastic. The Small Glories were excellent. Hugh's is small and intimate. A great spot to see any act.

reviews.title: Disappointed
text: I’ve been here many times, but my complaint remains the same....
The quality of the entertainment is always excellent, which is the reason I return......but the quality of the over priced food stinks.

The reality of  the venue in my view is....if you don’t book a table for dinner then the remaining seating is less than desirable. So now a $30 admission price jumps to about $60 with an over priced dinner. I’m being charitable when I refer to it as dinner.

Thirteen of us attended the We Banjo Three concert there on Friday night last, all of us agreed we would never again have dinner there. The drinks are also expensive and the service is extremely slow and disorganized.
But the music is always great.

reviews.title: Excellent music.....food much improved!
text: We saw Jeff Daniels + Ben Daniels Band last night and what a great show! I could have listened to the music and stories for alot longer than the two hour show. Now for the food: it's a new menu since we were there in March and I think it's a big improvement. It's sharing plates that arrived in a timely fashion. We had the olives, croquettes, caprese salad, roasted veg and bacon (!) popcorn. Everything was very good but portions are small for the price. This was our dinner and it was more than enough for the 2 of us. The value for us is in enjoying great music with an appreciative, respectful audience.

reviews.title: Dinner and Show
text: Hugh’s Room Live has a rich and important history in the Toronto music scene but unfortunately could not make a go of it and closed its doors a couple of years ago. Thankfully, a group of music lovers took it over and after heavy campaigning and fund raising, brought it back as a not for profit venue. I’m thankful for that. They have booked some wonderful acts over the months and I have attended my share of shows.

Having said that, they clearly need to bring someone in to revamp their food and beverage service. As this is primarily a dinner and music venue, you would think that they would offer a decent selection of food. But their menu choices are scant, their portions leave you feeling hungry and cheated and their prices way higher than their quality, and this has been going on since they reopened with seemingly no interest in changing and improving.

Case in point. Two weeks ago I ordered pork tenderloin. The portions of pork were ok but the taste was marginal. To accompany the pork they offered a tiny smattering of some sort of metallic tasting chutney and two halves of a tiny Parisian potato. That’s it. If I wasn’t so pissed off I would have found it laughable. The waiter was called over and to his credit, brought back two more potato halve a about eight green beans. But not after the meat was gone. However to their credit, my wife had their $21 burger and it was average.
The following week we went back to see Colin Linden. I thought I’d have the $21 burger but they were sold out. Really? How do you sell out a burger? The inmates are running the asylum.

Here’s the thing. If you want to see a show you pretty much have to book and prepay a table for dinner. That’s generally $30-50 per seat. However, their tables are mostly for 4 or more people and you have to book the full table. Too bad if you want to go out for a date night with just your special other. Further, you are assigned an exact time to show up which is 6:00 or 6:15 or 6:30 or 6:45. That’s very inconvenient if the show starts at 8:30 which they usually do. There’s very little flexibility with the times. I called last week to change my yin’s to 7:30 and was told that I could wait a long tine for my meal. I asked if that could be two hours and was told “maybe”. Really?

The thing is that this situation has been going on since it reopened. A year ago, on two occasions, we went to shows and had awful meals. I don’t even remember this issue but it was enough to write them a very polite and well intentioned letter telling of my experience. I received no reply. So I wrote them again. Same reply. None. So I boycotted them for a year. I went back two weeks ago as a test and nothing had changed.

Bottom line. If you are keen to see the shows and you don’t mind sitting on a stool at the back or standing, go. They offer great entertainment and Toronto needs that. But if you go expecting to get a good meal for a high end restaurant price, be prepared to be totally disappointed.

reviews.title: Great venue, nice staff, horrible horrible horrible food
text: A great listening lounge for music fans. Put away your phone, stop talking, listen to the people on stage! Three places where you must do music in Toronto: the legendary Horseshoe (they work really hard at keeping it a dive), Massey Hall and Hugh's.
But don't go to Hugh's for the food. It is possibly the worst meal I've had in a restaurant since Y2K. All four of the meals at our table were borderline inedible.
Hugh's is now a notforprofit so some of the staff is volunteer. Drinks from the bar are slow to come. But overall, a really good vibe.

reviews.title: First Timer Don't Let the Food Reviews Scare Ya!
text: My wife and I were over the moon regarding our Over The Rhine Experience. Wow is all I can say about the concert experience. We were first timers, and after reading the multiple negative reviews about the food we were really not too excited about that side of the event. We both attempted to order burgers believing that was the easiest to prepare successfully but alas they were " out of burgers" by the time we arrived (7 p.m.). As a "plan b", we both ordered the linguine it was great. Portions could have been larger, however, I am basically a swine that walks upright so I could say that about any dish that I liked at most restaurants. All in all, from this reviewer I hope you will not let what could be a musical dinner experience that has the potential to be as uplifting as ours was be missed because of old reviews. Thank You Hughs Room for a great experience!

reviews.title: WOW ... Christine Campbell and Blake Johnston!!
text: Just saw Christine Campbell and Blake Johnston at Hughs Room.  They were FANTASTIC.  We loved the venue, and the fact that it's a "listening room" so we could actually focus on the performance.  Great.

reviews.title: An expensive menu...
text: Really frustrated that they “ran out” of burgers - the lesser priced (but still expensive) meal on the very short menu. Apparently this happens frequently.

Figure it out, Hugh’s room - you need to either have more burgers on hand, or add some equivalent-priced meals to the menu. I spent more than $17.00 *extra ($38.00 total!) on the beef tenderloin; no matter that it is great, so were the burgers (going by the clean plates of our neighbours) and no discount was offered..
A nice venue, but get real.

reviews.title: Cheap and misleading
text: I'm very sad to write a negative review. I usually don't do it, if I'm unhappy with any experience, I just keep it to myself. However, this was truly bad Mother's Day Brunch! The 'Hugh's Room organized a Mother's Day Brunch with quite decent music by Tiki and few women singers, that was okay despite one of the singers (Lily Frost) bringing her kids to the stage - why? It was supposed to be a professional concert, not sing-along karaoke, eh ... Anyway, the kids were the least of the problem. The main issue is with the misleading tickets sale described as "Mother's Day Brunch Concert" $25.00 per person - that sounds OK, doesn't it? Well, at the end of the event, we've learnt that $25.00 was just for the Concert part, there was extra $25.00 for the Brunch part collected at the table. Very sneaky! Very misleading. The brunch itself was definitely not worth $25.00 - cold veggies, shredded pieces of cheese and overdone pancakes can hardly be worth that much! Never again! If one wants to have a good brunch with jazz, one should check Ricarda, or for the evening with jazz go to Smith Bar. Hugh's Room - NEVER AGAIN!

reviews.title: Great music, now great food
text: We reveled in Zoe Chilco’s “Songs to Inspire People who Give”, at Hugh’s Room, May 5. One of the top shows we have ever enjoyed at this venerable venue. We always enjoy dinner before the shows. Now hear this. There is a new chef in town, and the beef tenderloin I had was exquisite! Now there are two reasons to visit the best listening room in Toronto. Five star music meets five star food.

reviews.title: AMAZING PREFORMANCE BY MARTYN JOSEPH... Lousey dessert.
text: Ok...so we know it is expensive to go there. But if you're going to put out $100 for a couple of people for the meal  alone the least you could do is offer decent desserts. I absolutely do not recommend the vegan chocolate cake it was tasteless and a waste of $8. I know people have been commenting on how wonderful the food has been since there's a new chef. But I found the Cornish game hen sauce so salty it ruined the meal I couldn't even taste the meat. Other people at the table had different entrees and they enjoyed it very much. So I'm hoping the food will continue to improve. If you order the Cornish game hen ask for no sauce or sauce on the side. I did not say anything about the sauce because I had been taken there as a guest and my meal was being paid for by a friend. Under those circumstances one usually does not choose to file any complaints at the time.

reviews.title: Great JAZZ
text: Dinner was great mostly OK but the burger was red in the middle, under-cooked.
Most of the seats were set for meals although there was a bar with stools and plenty of standing room.
The sound stage is very nice and the Jazz/Blues was great. Headliner Tim Quinlan on guitar was outstanding.

reviews.title: Hugh's Room is Back as Toronto's #1 entertainment venue!!
text: Prior to going to Hugh's Room, I had read the reviews about the menu and the service. Well, let me tell you that someone there must have read the reviews and kicked some butt!! Our party of four had fantastic service.

Our meals were not only delicious but had huge portions! The prices at first seemed steep... but the burgers and the cornish hen were worth EVERY PENNY!!The draught selection was a little meagre for my tastes
but que sera, sera!! I drank enough anyway!!
